description: Derived from late Middle English queristre, from an Anglo-Norman variant of Old French cueriste, from cuer (see Middle French cuer). Equivalent to choir +â€Ž -ster.

examples: None of the new choristers can sing in tune but they will learn soon enough.

entries.meaning: A director or leader of a choral group.
examples: Jane was the chorister of her congregation's choir, and that occupied much of her time on the weekends.
